title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #804: Independent Sets in Locally Independent Graphs**

The problem asks: if EVERY small induced subgraph has a good independent set, how good must the GLOBAL independent set be?

Erdős and Hajnal conjectured optimistic bounds:
- f((log n)², n) ≥ n^(1/2 - o(1))
- f((log n)³, n) ≫ (log n)³

**Both were WRONG!** Alon-Sudakov (2007) proved the true answer is only (log n)² / log log n.
mathContext: This is a local-to-global structure problem. Local guarantees (every small subgraph has large independent set) don't translate to global guarantees as strongly as expected.

title: Independent Set Definition
content:
**IsIndependent G S:**

A set S of vertices is independent (or stable) if no two vertices in S are adjacent:
$$\forall u, v \in S, u \neq v \implies \neg G.\text{Adj}(u, v)$$

**Examples:**
- In any graph, {v} (singleton) is independent
- In K_n (complete graph), only singletons are independent
- In empty graph, any set is independent

title: Independence Number α(G)
content:
**independenceNumber G:**

α(G) = maximum size of an independent set in G.

**Examples:**
- α(K_n) = 1 (only singletons work)
- α(empty graph on n vertices) = n
- α(cycle C_n) = ⌊n/2⌋

Computing α(G) is NP-hard in general.

title: Local Independence Property
content:
**HasLocalIndependence G m k:**

A graph has the (m, k)-local independence property if EVERY induced subgraph on m vertices contains an independent set of size ≥ k.

**Interpretation:** This is a very strong condition! It says that no matter which m vertices you pick, you can find k non-adjacent ones among them.

The question: does this local guarantee force a large global independent set?

title: Conjecture 1 (Disproved)
content:
**erdos_hajnal_conjecture_1_false:**

Erdős-Hajnal conjectured: f((log n)², n) ≥ n^(1/2 - o(1))

This would mean: if every (log n)²-vertex subgraph has α ≥ log n, then the whole graph has α almost √n.

**DISPROVED!** The true bound is only Θ((log n)² / log log n), which is MUCH smaller than √n.

The conjecture was off by an exponential factor!

title: Conjecture 2 (Disproved)
content:
**erdos_hajnal_conjecture_2_false:**

Erdős-Hajnal conjectured: f((log n)³, n) ≫ (log n)³

This would mean: if every (log n)³-vertex subgraph has α ≥ log n, then the whole graph has α much larger than (log n)³.

**DISPROVED!** The true bound is only Θ((log n)² / log log n), which is smaller than (log n)³.

Remarkably, increasing m from (log n)² to (log n)³ doesn't significantly improve the global bound!

title: Alon-Sudakov Upper Bound
content:
**alon_sudakov_upper_bound_1:**

There exist graphs where:
- Every (log n)²-vertex subgraph has α ≥ log n
- But the global α is only O((log n)²)

**Construction idea:** Dense random graphs G(n, p) with p ≈ 1 - 1/log n have this property. They're dense enough that global α is small, but sparse enough locally to have good local independent sets.

title: Alon-Sudakov Lower Bound
content:
**alon_sudakov_lower_bound_1:**

Any graph where every (log n)²-vertex subgraph has α ≥ log n must have:
$$\alpha(G) \geq c \cdot \frac{(\log n)^2}{\log \log n}$$

**The log log n factor is crucial!** It appears mysteriously in many extremal combinatorics bounds.

Combined with the upper bound, this gives the tight characterization.

title: Tight Bound for (log n)³
content:
**alon_sudakov_tight_bound_2:**

$$f((\log n)^3, n) \asymp \frac{(\log n)^2}{\log \log n}$$

**Surprising fact:** The answer for m = (log n)³ is THE SAME as for m = (log n)² (up to constants)!

Increasing the local window size by a factor of log n doesn't help the global bound. The bottleneck is elsewhere.
mathContext: This shows a saturation effect: beyond a certain point, stronger local conditions don't improve global outcomes.

title: Main Theorem
content:
**erdos_804:**

Both original Erdős-Hajnal conjectures are FALSE:

1. f((log n)², n) ≱ n^(1/2 - o(1)) ✗
2. f((log n)³, n) ≯ (log n)³ ✗

The true answer in both cases is Θ((log n)² / log log n).

This completely resolves Erdős Problem #804 in the negative.

title: Random Graph Intuition
content:
**random_graph_intuition:**

Random graphs G(n, p) with p ≈ 1 - 1/log n provide counterexamples:

1. **Local structure:** In m-vertex induced subgraphs, ≈ m/log n vertices are expected to form an independent set (due to low local density).

2. **Global structure:** But globally, α(G) ≈ (log n)² because the overall edge density is high.

Random constructions often give optimal or near-optimal examples in extremal graph theory.
mathContext: The probabilistic method is a powerful tool: showing random objects have certain properties proves existence.

title: Ramsey Theory Connection
content:
**ramsey_connection:**

The problem connects to Ramsey theory:
- Local independence = controlling structure of small induced subgraphs
- Global independence = large-scale structure

Ramsey theory studies how local constraints force global patterns. Here, Erdős-Hajnal overestimated the forcing strength.

Note: This is DIFFERENT from the famous Erdős-Hajnal conjecture about forbidden induced subgraphs (which remains open).

title: Connection to Problem #805
content:
**related_to_805:**

Erdős Problem #805 asks closely related questions about local-to-global independence.

The Alon-Sudakov paper [AlSu07] resolves BOTH problems using similar techniques. If you understand #804, you understand the essence of #805 as well.

title: Summary
content:
**erdos_804_summary:**

**Erdős Problem #804: DISPROVED (Alon-Sudakov, 2007)**

**Original Questions:**
1. f((log n)², n) ≥ n^(1/2 - o(1))? **NO**
2. f((log n)³, n) ≫ (log n)³? **NO**

**True Bounds:**
1. f((log n)², n) = Θ((log n)² / log log n)
2. f((log n)³, n) = Θ((log n)² / log log n)

**Key Lesson:** Local structure → global structure is weaker than intuition suggests. The loss is measured by the mysterious log log n factor.
